conclusion: Let's analyze how the shadows will change based on the movement of the light source.
The first image shows four objects (a typewriter, an alarm clock, an egg, and a remote control) on a surface, casting shadows A, B, C, and D respectively.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are all cast generally downwards and slightly to the right relative to their objects from the camera's perspective.

premise: Shadows A, B, C, and D are all cast generally downwards and slightly to the right relative to their objects from the camera's perspective.
conclusion: This indicates that the light source is currently positioned somewhere above and to the left (relative to the objects and the camera's viewpoint).
Shadows are formed when an object blocks light.
The direction of the shadow is always opposite to the direction of the light source relative to the object.
The shadow is cast on a surface away from the object in the direction opposite the light source.
The length of the shadow depends on the angle of the light rays. A lower light source creates longer shadows.
The shape of the shadow is the projection of the object's outline onto the surface from the perspective of the light source.
The light source moves to the 'back left or right'.

premise: The light source moves to the 'back left or right'.
conclusion: Assuming 'back' means horizontally further away from the objects (and potentially lower) relative to the current position and the camera's viewpoint, and 'left/right' refers to the lateral movement.

premise: Currently, the light source is roughly in front and to the left, casting shadows back and to the right.
conclusion: Moving the light 'back' implies moving it behind the objects from the current viewpoint, away from the viewer, horizontally.

premise: If the light source moves to a position that is behind the objects (relative to the camera's view) and to the left, the shadows will be cast in the opposite direction.
conclusion: Shadows A, B, C, and D will shift their position from being behind/right of their objects to being in front/right of their objects.

premise: Moving the light source further away horizontally ('back') and potentially lower typically results in longer shadows being cast further away from the object on the surface.
conclusion: The shape of the shadows will also change as the angle of projection from the light source changes relative to the object's form.
